reported_speech_b2.title: Reported Speech
reported_speech_b2.subtitle: Reporting what someone said (Backshift the tense).
reported_speech_b2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson (B2)

1. Concept:
Reporting what someone else said.

2. Structure:

Subject + said (that) + [Backshifted Sentence]

3. Key Rules (Backshift):

  • Present Simple ➡️ Past Simple
  • Will ➡️ Would
  • Can ➡️ Could

4. Examples:
Direct: "I like tea."
Reported: "He said usually he liked tea."

💡 Tip: 'That' is optional. "He said (that) he was busy."

explorer.correctSentence: He said he was happy
He said she worked there
She said she liked it
They said they were tired
He said he had a car
He said he was leaving the next day
explorer.hint: Time shift: tomorrow ➡️ the next day.

explorer.original: Direct: 'I will do it next week.'
explorer.correctSentence: He said he would do it the following week
explorer.hint: Time shift: next week ➡️ the following week.

explorer.correctSentence: He said she was staying there
She said she had seen him the day before
explorer.hint: Time shift: yesterday ➡️ the day before. Past Simple ➡️ Past Perfect.

explorer.correctSentence: They said they were meeting that night

scholar.correctSentence: He said he would call me
She said she could help
He said he had to go
He said he was not coming
She said I looked tired
He asked me to help him
He told me not to touch that
He offered to drive me
He advised me to see a doctor
He asked why I was late

specialist.correctSentence: He said he had visited Paris
He asked where I was
He asked if I liked it
He said he had been working
specialist.hint: Present Perfect Continuous ➡️ Past Perfect Continuous.

specialist.correctSentence: He told me not to go

specialist.original: Direct: 'If I were you, I would go.'
specialist.correctSentence: He said that if he were me he would go

specialist.original: Direct: 'I must have left it at home.'
specialist.correctSentence: He said he must have left it at home
specialist.hint: Modals of deduction (must have) don't change.

specialist.original: Direct: 'Unless you help, I can't finish.'
specialist.correctSentence: He said unless I helped he couldn't finish
He said he wished he had known
He insisted that I report that immediately

passive_voice_b2.title: Passive Voice
passive_voice_b2.subtitle: Focusing on the action, not the doer.
passive_voice_b2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson (A2-B1)

1. Concept:
When the object of the action is more important than the subject.

2. Structure:

Object + be + Past Participle (V3) (+ by Subject)

3. Tense Changes:

  • Present: am/is/are done
  • Past: was/were done
  • Future: will be done

4. Examples:
✅ "The book was written by JK Rowling."
✅ "Dinner is served at 8pm."

explorer.correctSentence: The email is written every day
Cars are made in Germany
The office is cleaned by him
The cake is eaten by us
Apples are grown here
The room is being cleaned
explorer.hint: Present Continuous Passive: is being + V3.

explorer.correctSentence: The car is being washed
explorer.hint: Present Continuous Passive: is being + V3.

explorer.correctSentence: Dinner is being cooked
explorer.hint: Present Continuous Passive: is being + V3.

explorer.correctSentence: The road was being fixed
explorer.hint: Past Continuous Passive: was being + V3.

explorer.correctSentence: We are being watched
explorer.hint: Present Continuous Passive: are being + V3.

scholar.correctSentence: My bike was stolen yesterday
The house was built in 1990
We were not invited to the party
scholar.hint: Past Simple Passive Negative: were not invited.

scholar.correctSentence: The letter was written by her
Was the car fixed
scholar.hint: Pas Simple Passive Question: Was... fixed?

scholar.correctSentence: My wallet has been stolen
scholar.hint: Present Perfect Passive: has been + V3.

scholar.correctSentence: The flight has been cancelled
scholar.hint: Present Perfect Passive: has been + V3.

scholar.original: She had already finished the work.
scholar.correctSentence: The work had already been finished
scholar.hint: Past Perfect Passive: had been + V3.

scholar.original: They have not sent the email.
scholar.correctSentence: The email has not been sent
Has the cat been fed

specialist.correctSentence: The job will be finished soon
My phone has been taken
specialist.hint: Present Perfect Passive: has been taken.

specialist.correctSentence: The song can be heard everywhere
It must be done today
He should be told
It is said that he is rich
specialist.hint: Impersonal Passive: It is said that...

specialist.correctSentence: She is believed to be hiding
specialist.hint: Personal Passive Structure: Subject + Passive Verb + Infinitive.

specialist.original: We will have finished the project by 5.
specialist.correctSentence: The project will have been finished by 5

specialist.original: I don't like people staring at me.
specialist.correctSentence: I do not like being stared at

specialist.original: She got someone to fix the roof.
specialist.correctSentence: She had the roof fixed

third_conditional_b2.title: Third Conditional
third_conditional_b2.subtitle: Regrets about the past (If + Had V3, ... Would Have V3).
third_conditional_b2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson (B2)

1. Concept:
Imaginary situations in the past (Regrets).

2. Structure:

If + Past Perfect, ... Would Have + V3

3. Examples:
✅ "If I had known, I would have come."

explorer.correctSentence: If I had known I would have helped
explorer.hint: If + had known... would have helped.

explorer.correctSentence: If she had studied she would have passed
explorer.hint: If + had studied... would have passed.

explorer.correctSentence: If it had rained we would have stayed home
explorer.hint: If + had rained... would have stayed.

explorer.correctSentence: He would have won if he had tried
explorer.hint: Would have won... if + had tried.

explorer.correctSentence: I would have called if I had had time

scholar.correctSentence: If they had invited us we would have gone
She would not have been late if she had left earlier
If I had seen you I would have said hello
What would you have done if you had failed
If the car had not broken we would have arrived

specialist.original: If I (know) you were coming, I (bake) a cake.
specialist.correctSentence: If I had known you were coming I would have baked a cake
You could have saved time if you had asked
specialist.hint: Could have (ability/possibility) instead of would have.

specialist.correctSentence: If only I had listened to you
specialist.hint: If only + Past Perfect for regret.

specialist.correctSentence: She might have passed if she had studied
Had I known I would have gone
specialist.hint: Inversion: Had I known (instead of If I had known).

mixed_conditionals_b2.title: Mixed Conditionals
mixed_conditionals_b2.subtitle: Past cause, present result (If + Past Perfect, ... Would + Verb).
mixed_conditionals_b2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson (B2)

1. Concept:
Something happened in the past, but the result is now.

2. Structure:

If + Past Perfect (Past Cause), ... Would + Verb (Present Result)

3. Examples:
✅ "If I had eaten lunch, I would not be hungry now."

explorer.original: If I (eat) lunch, I (not/be) hungry now.
explorer.correctSentence: If I had eaten lunch I would not be hungry now

explorer.original: If he (study) harder, he (be) a doctor now.
explorer.correctSentence: If he had studied harder he would be a doctor now

explorer.original: If we (book) tickets, we (be) in Paris.
explorer.correctSentence: If we had booked tickets we would be in Paris
I would be happy if I had won yesterday

explorer.original: If she (born) in US, she (speak) English.
explorer.correctSentence: If she had been born in the US she would speak English

scholar.original: If you (finish) your work, you (be) free.
scholar.correctSentence: If you had finished your work you would be free

scholar.original: If I (not/lose) my keys, I (be) home.
scholar.correctSentence: If I had not lost my keys I would be home

scholar.original: If they (catch) the train, they (be) here.
scholar.correctSentence: If they had caught the train they would be here
She would not be tired if she had slept

scholar.original: If I (take) the job, I (live) in Rome.
scholar.correctSentence: If I had taken the job I would live in Rome

specialist.original: If I (be) rich, I (buy) that car yesterday.
specialist.correctSentence: If I were rich I would have bought that car yesterday
specialist.hint: Type 2 to Type 3 Mix: Permanent state (rich) -> Past action.

specialist.original: If she (speak) Greek, she (help) you yesterday.
specialist.correctSentence: If she spoke Greek she would have helped you yesterday

specialist.original: If I (not/spend) all my money, I (be) rich.
specialist.correctSentence: If I had not spent all my money I would be rich

specialist.original: We (be) on the beach if it (not/rain).
specialist.correctSentence: We would be on the beach if it had not rained

specialist.original: If he (be) a good leader, he (not/make) that mistake.
specialist.correctSentence: If he were a good leader he would not have made that mistake

past_perfect_continuous_b2.title: Past Perfect Continuous
past_perfect_continuous_b2.subtitle: Duration before a past moment (Had Been -ing).
past_perfect_continuous_b2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson (B2)

1. Concept:
Action happening for a duration before something else in the past.

2. Structure:

Subject + had been + Verb-ing

3. Use it for:
Showing cause (tired because...) or duration (for 2 hours when...).

4. Example:
✅ "He was tired because he had been running."

explorer.original: She (wait) for an hour when he arrived.
explorer.correctSentence: She had been waiting for an hour when he arrived

explorer.original: They (play) football so they were dirty.
explorer.correctSentence: They had been playing football so they were dirty
explorer.hint: Reason for past state: had been playing.

explorer.correctSentence: He had been working there since 2010
explorer.hint: Duration up to a past point.

explorer.correctSentence: I had been sleeping when you called
explorer.hint: Action in progress up to call (or was sleeping - slightly different nuance but ppc focuses on duration).

explorer.correctSentence: It had been raining all day

scholar.original: She tired because she (drive) all day.
scholar.correctSentence: She was tired because she had been driving all day
How long had you been waiting
The road was wet it had been raining

scholar.original: He (try) to open the jar for minutes.
scholar.correctSentence: He had been trying to open the jar for minutes

scholar.original: She gained weight because she (eat) too much.
scholar.correctSentence: She gained weight because she had been eating too much
scholar.hint: Habit over a period in past.

specialist.original: I (look) forward to it for ages.
specialist.correctSentence: I had been looking forward to it for ages

specialist.original: He ended up in hospital; he (drink).
specialist.correctSentence: He ended up in hospital he had been drinking

specialist.original: They (discuss) the issue for days prior.
specialist.correctSentence: They had been discussing the issue for days prior
The detective knew he had been lying
I had been minding my own business when

future_perfect_b2.title: Future Perfect
future_perfect_b2.subtitle: Completed before a future time (Will Have V3).
future_perfect_b2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson (B2)

1. Concept:
An action that will be finished before a specific time in the future.

2. Structure:

Subject + will have + V3 (Past Participle)

3. Use with:
By tomorrow, by next year, by 5 PM.

4. Example:
✅ "By 2030, humans will have landed on Mars."

explorer.correctSentence: I will have finished by 5 PM

explorer.original: She (leave) by the time you arrive.
explorer.correctSentence: She will have left by the time you arrive
We will have eaten dinner by then
He will have fixed the car by tomorrow
They will have arrived by noon

scholar.correctSentence: You will have graduated by next year
I will have read the book by Sunday
They will have built the house by winter
We will have been married for 10 years soon
She will have saved enough money by June

specialist.original: By the time we land, we (fly) for 12 hours.
specialist.correctSentence: By the time we land we will have been flying for 12 hours

specialist.original: I (finish) everything by the time you wake up.
specialist.correctSentence: I will have finished everything by the time you wake up
The snow will have melted by March

specialist.original: The meeting (start) before we get there.
specialist.correctSentence: The meeting will have started before we get there

specialist.original: He (spend) all of it by then.
specialist.correctSentence: He will have spent all of it by then

causative_verbs_b2.title: Causative Verbs
causative_verbs_b2.subtitle: Arranging for someone else to do something (Have/Get something done).
causative_verbs_b2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson (B2)

1. Concept:
You pay or ask someone else to do a service for you.

2. Structure:

Subject + Have / Get + Object + V3

3. Examples:
✅ "I had my car fixed." (I didn't fix it myself).
✅ "She is getting her hair cut."

explorer.correctSentence: I had my hair cut yesterday
She is getting her car washed now
We had the house painted

explorer.original: He (need) to get his watch fixed.
explorer.correctSentence: He needs to get his watch fixed
I had my eyes tested

scholar.original: How often do you (have) your teeth cleaned?
scholar.correctSentence: How often do you have your teeth cleaned

scholar.original: I need to (get) the roof repaired.
scholar.correctSentence: I need to get the roof repaired
She had the dress made specially
We will have the package delivered
He got his passport renewed

specialist.correctSentence: You should have it checked

specialist.original: I won't (have) you speak to me like that!
specialist.correctSentence: I won't have you speak to me like that
He got me to help him
I made him apologize
She let him go

modals_probability_past_b2.title: Modals of Probability (Past)
modals_probability_past_b2.subtitle: Deducting what happened (Must have / Can't have).
modals_probability_past_b2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson (B2)

1. Concept:
Guessing about the past with different levels of certainty.

2. Scale:

  • 99% Sure (Yes): Must have + V3
  • 50% Possible: Might/May/Could have + V3
  • 99% Sure (No): Can't have + V3

3. Example:
✅ "The streets are wet. It must have rained."

explorer.correctSentence: It must have rained

explorer.original: She is late. She (might / miss) the bus.
explorer.correctSentence: She might have missed the bus
He must have won

explorer.original: It wasn't him. He (can't / do) it.
explorer.correctSentence: He can't have done it
I could have lost it there

scholar.original: The food is gone. They (must / eat) it.
scholar.correctSentence: They must have eaten it
She may have forgotten

scholar.original: You (can't / see) him; he was away.
scholar.correctSentence: You can't have seen him
He must have been sleeping
They might have taken the wrong road

specialist.correctSentence: It could not have been easier
You should have called me
specialist.hint: Criticism/Regret (different from probability, but related modals structure).

specialist.original: She (must / work) hard to get that.
specialist.correctSentence: She must have worked hard to get that
I need not have brought an umbrella
specialist.hint: Lack of necessity in past (didn't need to).

specialist.correctSentence: He could have hurt himself

relative_clauses_advanced_b2.title: Relative Clauses (Advanced)
relative_clauses_advanced_b2.subtitle: Non-defining, Whose, and Whom.
relative_clauses_advanced_b2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson (B2)

1. Non-defining:
Extra info (with commas). "My brother, who lives in NY, is rich." (I might have only one brother).

2. Whose:
Possession. "The boy whose bike was stolen."

3. Whom:
Object form of who (formal). "The man with whom I spoke."

explorer.original: My mom, (who / live) in London, is a doctor.
explorer.correctSentence: My mom who lives in London is a doctor

explorer.original: That is the man (car) was stolen.
explorer.correctSentence: That is the man whose car was stolen

explorer.original: The person (whom) I met was nice.
explorer.correctSentence: The person whom I met was nice

explorer.original: My car, (which / be) blue, is fast.
explorer.correctSentence: My car which is blue is fast
Paris where I went is beautiful

scholar.correctSentence: The friend with whom I went
The company for which I work

scholar.original: My boss, (whose) wife is French, speaks French.
scholar.correctSentence: My boss whose wife is French speaks French

scholar.original: The reason (why) I came is secret.
scholar.correctSentence: The reason why I came is secret

scholar.original: He tore the letter, (which / upset) me.
scholar.correctSentence: He tore the letter which upset me
scholar.hint: Sentence relative clause: 'which' refers to the action.

specialist.correctSentence: The bed in which I slept
All of whom were late

specialist.original: Two men, neither of (whom) I knew.
specialist.correctSentence: Two men neither of whom I knew
The point at which we stopped

specialist.original: The evidence, on the basis of (which), he was released.
specialist.correctSentence: The evidence on the basis of which he was released

gerunds_infinitives_complex_b2.title: Gerunds & Infinitives (Complex)
gerunds_infinitives_complex_b2.subtitle: Verbs changing meaning (Stop to smoke vs. Stop smoking).
gerunds_infinitives_complex_b2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson (B2)

1. Stop to do: Stop an action in order to do something else.
✅ "He stopped (walking) to smoke."

2. Stop doing: Quit the action forever.
✅ "He stopped smoking."

3. Remember/Forget: To do (future task) vs Doing (past memory).

explorer.correctSentence: I stopped buying coffee
We stopped to get gas
explorer.hint: Stopped in order to do it.

explorer.correctSentence: Remember to lock the door
I remember seeing him
Try opening the window

scholar.correctSentence: I regret to tell you that
I regret telling him the secret

scholar.original: He went on (talk) about his trip.
scholar.correctSentence: He went on talking about his trip
He went on to become a doctor
Don't forget to call your mom

specialist.correctSentence: I mean to work hard
This means waking up early
I never meant to hurt you

specialist.original: Try (change) the battery; it might work.
specialist.correctSentence: Try changing the battery it might work

specialist.original: I tried (lift) it but it was heavy.
specialist.correctSentence: I tried to lift it but it was heavy

linking_words_contrast_b2.title: Linking Words (Contrast)
linking_words_contrast_b2.subtitle: Connecting opposing ideas (Although, Despite, However).
linking_words_contrast_b2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson (B2)

1. Although / Even though: + Subject + Verb.
✅ "Although it rained, we went."

2. Despite / In spite of: + Noun / -ing.
✅ "Despite the rain, we went."

3. However: Start new sentence (comma).
✅ "It rained. However, we went."

explorer.correctSentence: Although it rained we played
Despite the rain we played

explorer.original: He is rich. (However), he is sad.
explorer.correctSentence: He is rich However he is sad

explorer.original: (Even though) I was tired, I ran.
explorer.correctSentence: Even though I was tired I ran

explorer.original: In spite of (work) hard, he failed.
explorer.correctSentence: In spite of working hard he failed

scholar.correctSentence: Despite being ill she came

scholar.original: I like him. (Nevertheless), I can't stay.
scholar.correctSentence: I like him Nevertheless I can't stay

scholar.original: (Whereas) I am quiet, he is loud.
scholar.correctSentence: Whereas I am quiet he is loud

scholar.original: Expensive (as) it is, I want it.
scholar.correctSentence: Expensive as it is I want it

scholar.original: Much (as) I like you, I must go.
scholar.correctSentence: Much as I like you I must go

specialist.correctSentence: Hard though he tried he failed

specialist.original: Strange (as) it may seem, it's true.
specialist.correctSentence: Strange as it may seem it's true
She went out notwithstanding the storm

specialist.original: Be that as it (may), we must continue.
specialist.correctSentence: Be that as it may we must continue
He refused albeit politely

indirect_questions_b2.title: Indirect Questions
indirect_questions_b2.subtitle: Polite questions (Do you know where it is?).
indirect_questions_b2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson (B2)

1. Concept:
Making questions softer or more polite.

2. Structure:

Phrase + Question Word + Subject + Verb

3. Rules:
No "do/did" auxiliary. Normal sentence order after the question word.
✅ "Where is it?" ➡️ "Do you know where it is?"

explorer.correctSentence: Do you know where the bank is
Can you tell me what time it is
I wonder who that is
Do you know why they are crying
Can you say when it starts

scholar.correctSentence: Do you know if he left
I ask where she went
Could you tell me how much it costs
I don't know whether he is married
I have no idea what this means

specialist.original: Could you tell me where (is the station)?
specialist.correctSentence: Could you tell me where the station is

specialist.original: I was wondering if (could you) help.
specialist.correctSentence: I was wondering if you could help
Can I ask who gave it to you
Do you know what happened
May I ask to whom you spoke

inversion_b2.title: Inversion
inversion_b2.subtitle: Emphasis by changing word order (Never have I...).
inversion_b2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson (B2)

1. Concept:
Used for emphasis, usually with negative adverbs at the start.

2. Structure:

Negative Adverb + Auxiliary + Subject + Verb

3. Common Adverbs:
Never, Rarely, Seldom, Little, Under no circumstances.

4. Example:
✅ "Never have I seen such a thing." (Instead of "I have never seen...")

explorer.correctSentence: Never have I seen this
Rarely do I go there
Seldom does he speak
Scarcely had I arrived when
Never should you do that

scholar.correctSentence: Little did he know the truth

scholar.original: You must not go under any circumstances.
scholar.correctSentence: Under no circumstances must you go

scholar.original: I not only sang, but I danced.
scholar.correctSentence: Not only did I sing but I danced

scholar.original: As soon as he arrived, he left.
scholar.correctSentence: No sooner had he arrived than he left
Only then did I understand

specialist.original: Only by working hard can you succeed.
specialist.correctSentence: Only by working hard can you succeed
So beautiful was she that

specialist.original: Had I seen him, I would have stopped.
specialist.correctSentence: Had I seen him I would have stopped

specialist.original: Were I you, I would go.
specialist.correctSentence: Were I you I would go

specialist.original: Should you need help, call me.
specialist.correctSentence: Should you need help call me
